column8:
For the secret conspiracy theorists in all of us, the idea that Christopher Marlowe faked his own death, only to continue writing under his new name of William Shakespeare, has a certain appeal. After all, no one really knows what Shakespeare looked like. Accused of blasphemy, libel and of being a spy. Marlowe's  life, it seems, was as dramatic as the plays he both wrote and allegedly wrote.

This design plays with the idea of that conspiracy, whilst puckishly inverting it.
column21: Christopher Marlowe as poet and playwright was at the forefront of the 16th Century dramatic renaissance, a man to whom Shakespeare and others owe a huge debt of gratitude. Show your admiration for him with this unique t-shirt from weadmire.net.

column8: Art Deco is one of my favourite art movements because of its decorative nature and the beautiful patterns designs that emerged in its era from the 1925 until the 1940s.  I wanted to take an element of art deco and combine it with a different decade and also a subject that it also beautiful and eye catching, womens' legs.  The design is inspired from Taschen's 'The big Book of Legs' and from art deco graphic patterns.
column21: The design is inspired from Taschen's 'The big Book of Legs' and from art deco graphic patterns.

column8:
This design admires the Dino, produced between 1968 and 1976.

Built by Ferrari, but not officially badged as a Ferrari, the Dino was a beautiful little sports car with a V6 engine rather than the standard 12 cylinder engines that Ferrari were then famous for.

The Dino engine was designed by Enzo's son, Alfredo "Dino" Ferrari.

It was basically an attempt by Ferrari to produce a smaller, lighter and ultimately cheaper car that could compete with relatively cheaper Porsches that were outselling the more expensive Ferrari's.

Enzo was unsure of this idea, but was willing to give it a go, as long as it didn't tarnish the Ferrari reputation, hence the different name.

 

These shirts are printed on the front and back. The line drawing to the back of the shirt with the filled illustration on to the front. The filled illustration is printed at 800 dpi.

All shirts in this series are designed in Adobe Illustrator by Yukio Miyamoto  and are £40.

 

Other designs in this series are: Leica Camera  - V-Twin Motorcycle  - Fat Boy Motorcycle  - French Horn  -Lancer Evo Differential  - Nagra Audio Recorder  -
column21: This t-shirt admires the Dino, produced between 1968 and 1976. The Dino engine was designed by Enzo's son, Alfredo "Dino" Ferrari.

column8: Donna Summer - Disco is a derided era in music history when it presided over a period of escapism and much happiness and self expression for many people, and the music that accompanied it is the sound to so much liberation. Sexual, racial, physical, creative, gender. There are a few who would claim the crown of The Queen of Disco but as far as I am concerned only one to ever actually sit on the throne. When Donna summer sings "Love to Love you baby", your mind warps to a Studio 54 night, a decadent time and a total belief that she absolutely means it.
column21: The Queen of Disco, Donna Summer is celebrated here in this fabulous t-shirt from We Admire.net
